page.title: Concerns and controversies at the 2014 Asian Games

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{cleanup|reason= Judgement required as to what is and isn't a controversy. Pruning required of unimportant and trivial information. Consider [[Talk:2014 Asian Games|discussing]] with other editors first, as they may disagree with your definition of unimportant and trivial.|date=October 2014}} {{2014 Asian Games}} A number of concerns and controversies surfaced before and during the [[2014 Asian Games]] in [[Incheon]], South Korea, which received varying amounts of negative media coverage both domestically and internationally due to its unsportmanlike behaviour.
==Prior to the Games==
===Sponsorship and organization=== The Games were hit by lack of sponsorship and a lack of interest from the public with only 18% of the tickets for the opening ceremony sold a week before the Games.<ref>{{cite news|title=Debts and empty seats taint start of 2014 Asian Games at Incheon|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/debts-and-empty-seats-taint-start-of-2014-asian-games-at-incheon|accessdate=27 September 2014|publisher=The National Sport|date=19 September 2014}}</ref> Organizers were able to generate more interest but there were a few hundred empty seats in the 61,000-capacity stadium at the start of the opening ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games gets off to ‘Gangnam Style’ start |url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/sports/article/asian-games-gets-off-to-gangnam-style-start|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=The Malay Mail Online|date=19 September 2014}}</ref> There was a shortage of free shuttles provided for journalists and athletes in the days leading up to the Games.<ref>{{cite news|title=亚运交通让人心塞 场馆分布分散需搭区间车前往|url=http://www.hinews.cn/news/system/2014/09/19/016968275.shtml|accessdate=27 September 2014|publisher=hinews.cn|date=19 September 2014}}</ref> Organizers supplied more shuttle buses for the late-night shifts at the request of various international media organizations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Isacc|first1=Alex|title=[Asian Games] IBC, the home to CCTV and NHK for 2014 Incheon Asian Games|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20141001000798|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=Korea Herald|date=1 October 2014}}</ref>
When the identity of the final torch bearer was revealed to be the actress [[Lee Young-ae]], there were mixed reactions in the local press as she had no direct ties to sports. However, she ultimately passed the torch to a pair of young South Korean athletes and the three lighted the cauldron in unison.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jee-ho|first1=Yoo|title=(Asiad) Celebrity with no sports connection lights Asiad cauldron|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/culturesports/2014/09/19/30/0701000000AEN20140919011000315F.html|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=Yonhap News Agency|date=19 September 2014}}</ref>
===Honorary ambassadors dropped from set-list=== The honorary ambassadors of the Games, Korean group [[JYJ]], were reportedly dropped from the opening and closing ceremonies and were relegated to perform in the pre-opening ceremony instead,<ref>{{cite news|title=JYJ excluded from Incheon Asian Games opener |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/jyj-excluded-from-incheon-asian-games-opener/ |accessdate=4 July 2014 |publisher=ManilaBulletin |date=2 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714173812/http://www.mb.com.ph/jyj-excluded-from-incheon-asian-games-opener/ |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=JYJ 측 공식입장 "인천AG 약속 지켜달라, 불공정 외압 아니길" [전문]|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20140701n30920|accessdate=2 July 2014|publisher=NATE|date=1 July 2014}}</ref> Other confirmed artists such as [[Psy]], [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|Big Bang]], [[CNBLUE]] and [[Exo (band)|Exo]] will continue to perform on stage during the opening and closing ceremonies.<ref>{{cite news|title=싸이·빅뱅·JYJ·엑소, 2014인천AG 개폐막식 선다|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=shm&sid1=106&oid=109&aid=0002817426|accessdate=4 July 2014|publisher=KoreaHerald|date=1 July 2014}}</ref> After the news broke out, fans asked IAG for fair treatment of the group.<ref>{{cite news|author=Xiaolong|title=JYJ dropped from IAG opening and closing performances?|url=http://www.hellokpop.com/2014/07/04/jyj-dropped-from-iag-opening-and-closing-performances/|accessdate=6 July 2014|publisher=Hellokpop|date=4 July 2014}}</ref> Eventually, the JYJ sang the official song of the Games.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Min-jin|first1=Kim|title=JYJ to perform at Incheon Asiad opening ceremony|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20140820000969|accessdate=21 August 2014|publisher=The Korea Herald|date=20 August 2014}}</ref>
===Nationality issues=== In basketball, [[Olympic Council of Asia]]'s eligibility rule on naturalized players, which contradicted the eligibility rule set by [[FIBA]], became controversial as such rule disqualified [[Quincy Davis (basketball)|Quincy Davis]], a [[United States|US]]-born player playing for the Chinese Taipei team, and [[Andray Blatche]], a naturalized player of the Philippines, from participating in the tournament.<ref name="US-born">{{cite news|last1=Badua|first1=Shelley|title=US-born player no longer eligible for Asian Games|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/09/05/2003599061|accessdate=7 September 2014|publisher=Taipei Times|date=5 September 2014}}</ref> In accordance with the rule, OCA also refused South Korea's request to include Aaron Haynes in the squad, an American veteran player in [[Korean Basketball League|Korea's basketball league]] who was in the process of naturalization.<ref name="US-born2">{{cite news|last1=Flojo|first1=Enzo|title=Previewing the Asian Games basketball qualifiers|url=http://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/basketball/69601-previewing-the-asian-games-basketball|accessdate=20 September 2014|publisher=Rappler|date=19 September 2014}}</ref> Both OCA officials and IAGOC claimed that the OCA's eligibility rule requires a naturalized player to live minimum of three years in the country of his naturalization before becoming eligible to play for that country.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pedralvez|first1=Manolo|title=SBP hints Gilas Asian Games boycott after OCA bars Blatche|url=http://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/basketball/gilas-pilipinas/68529-sbp-gilas-asian-games-boycott-blatche|accessdate=20 September 2014|publisher=Rappler|date=8 September 2014}}</ref> Nevertheless, Chinese Taipei Basketball Association stated that it received the positive confirmation from OCA regarding the participation of Quincy Davis, which was suddenly overturned due to the fact that Davis was two months short from residing three full years in Chinese Taipei. Many basketball fans argued that the host nation South Korea brought up the regulation rule at the last minute in order to not allow enough time for its major opponents to reconstruct their squads. Meanwhile, South Korea claimed it was just enforcing the OCA's regulation and the South Korean team themselves were also negatively affected by the rule.<ref name="US-born"/><ref name="US-born2"/> Despite the request of FIBA to reconsider the enforcement of the eligibility rule, both OCA and the organizing committee upheld their decision.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lagunzad|first1=Chris|title=FIBA backs Gilas for Andray Blatche’s eligibility in the Asian Games|url=https://ph.sports.yahoo.com/news/fiba-backs-gilas-for-andray-blatche-s-eligibility-for-the-asian-games-070455242.html|accessdate=20 September 2014|publisher=Taipei Times|date=6 September 2014}}</ref>
===Female participants and FIBA ban on hijab=== Saudi Arabia was the only participating NOC to not send female athletes to the Games despite international pressure from organizations including the [[Human Rights Watch]]. The country was accused of taking a step backwards from the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], the first time in Olympics history that Saudi Arabia lifted its ban on female participation.<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/jul/11/london-2012-saudi-arabia-female-athletes|title=London 2012: IOC in talks with Saudi Arabia over female athletes | Sport | theguardian.com|publisher=guardian.co.uk|accessdate=3 October 2014|date=11 July 2012}}</ref> Mohammed al-Mishal, the secretary-general of Saudi Arabia's Olympic Committee, stated that women weren't included because none have reached the level for international competition.<ref>{{cite news|title=Saudi Arabia urged to end discrimination in women's sports|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/saudi-arabia-urged-end-discrimination-in-women-s-sports-566004.html|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=Arabian Business|date=26 September 2014}}</ref> A member of the Saudi Olympic committee later stated that the country plans to send women to compete at the [[2016 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: Women sidelined as Saudi Arabia selects all-male team|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/08/us-games-asian-saudi-women-idUSKBN0H31HI20140908|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=Reuters|date=8 September 2014}}</ref>
Qatar women's basketball team was hit by FIBA ban on Muslim [[headscarf]], known as [[hijab]]. They were scheduled to play Mongolia but were disallowed. The team eventually withdrew from the tournament, refusing to remove the hijab.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Talmadge|first1=Eric|title=Qatar Women Withdraw Over Asian Games Hijab Ban|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/qatar-forfeits-game-protest-hijab-ruling-25719857|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=abc News|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> FIBA claimed the ban was made due to safety concerns.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hijab issue, drug controversies hit Asian Games|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/asiangames2014/story/380855/hijab-issue-drug-controversies-hit-asian-games|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=GMA News|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> Qatar officials said the decision was insulting, disrespectful of the religion, and nonsensical as [[combat sports]] allow the hijab.<ref>{{cite news|last1=France-Presse|first1=Agence|title=Asian Games: Hijab Ban an Insult, Say Qatar Basketball Players|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/asian-games-2014/news/230452-asian-games-hijab-ban-an-insult-say-qatar-basketball-players|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=NDTV Sports|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> One player stated that they had been assured well before the Games that they would be able to wear hijab.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: Qatar women's team pull out over hijab ban|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/basketball/29342986|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 September 2014}}</ref>
===Cycling venue=== In cycling, Hong Kong cyclists had raised concerns after they found the competition venue would be an outdoor velodrome of 333 metres in length, instead of a 250 metres indoor velodrome, which is commonly in use during the [[Cycling at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] and the [[UCI Track Cycling World Cup|World Cup]]. [[Hong Kong Cycling Association]] claimed that outdoor velodromes are rare in modern cycling and they have to travel far to practice in a similar environment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong raise alarm over Asian Games old-style cycling track|url=http://www.scmp.com/sport/hong-kong/article/1458744/hong-kong-raise-alarm-over-asian-games-old-style-cycling-track|accessdate=13 April 2014|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=27 March 2014}}</ref> The organising committee denied any advantage to the host nation. They also claimed that the track was re-coated and received approval from [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI).<ref>{{cite news|last=Butler|first=Nick|title=Incheon 2014 unconcerned by criticism over track cycling venue at Asian Games|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/major-games/asian-games/1019226-incheon-2014-unconcerned-by-criticism-over-track-cycling-venue-at-asian-games|accessdate=13 April 2014|newspaper=inside the games|date=2 April 2014}}</ref>
==Competition issues==
===Women's 10 meter air-rifle===
The Chinese team was initially disqualified after shooter Zhang Binbin was found to have violated regulations concerning maximum weight limits of her rifle. The disqualification was eventually reversed after a strong appeal by Chinese officials arguing that Zhang "didn't intend to break the rule". This allowed China to retain their team gold and a new world record.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Oh|first1=Seok-min|title=(Asiad) China gets world record back in women's 10ｍ air rifle after ruling reversal|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/yonhap-news-agency/140922/asiad-china-gets-world-record-back-womens-10-air-rifle-aft-0|accessdate=22 September 2014|publisher=Yonhap News Agency|date=22 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rutherford|first1=Peter|title=China shooters DQ'd, reinstated, set world record|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2014/09/22/games-asian-shooting-idINKCN0HH0RA20140922|accessdate=22 September 2014|publisher=Reuters|date=22 September 2014}}</ref> This led to a series of allegations that members of jury favoured Zhang.<ref>{{cite news|title=Judoka Jeong defends Asiad title|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/sports/2014/09/207_165023.html|accessdate=23 September 2014|publisher=The Korea Times|date=22 September 2014}}</ref>
===Badminton===
In badminton, Chinese coach [[Li Yongbo]] accused the hosts of manipulating the wind in the stadium, after China was defeated by South Korea in the final of the men's team event. Yongbo said, "We did not lose because of technique or tactics, but due to some man-made reasons. The South Koreans deliberately controlled the wind blow in the stadium and took advantage of it." Japanese coach [[Keita Masuda]] also alleged a similar case saying, "The wind in this stadium is very strange, always supporting the hosts. Every time we change sides, the wind seems to change sides as well."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Noel Cudaihl|first1=Justin|title=2014 Asian Games Results Tainted By Rampant Cheating Allegations Hurled Against Hosts South Korea|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/568500/20141003/asian-games-korea-cheating-boxing-badminton-football.htm#.VC6d5BbTiop|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=International Business Times|date=3 October 2014}}</ref> Thailand's [[Ratchanok Intanon]], a former world champion, also went on to blame the "strangely strong winds" for her defeat in the quarterfinals of the women's singles event against a South Korean opponent.<ref name=thenation>{{cite news|title=A host country's sporting bias is fool's gold|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/opinion/A-host-countrys-sporting-bias-is-fools-gold-30244556.html|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=The Nation|date=2 October 2014}}</ref>
===Boxing officiating=== Indian lightweight boxer [[Laishram Sarita Devi]] lost a highly controversial 60 kg semi-final bout against eventual silver medalist Park Jina of South Korea. Despite what many believed was a better performance by Sarita Devi, all three ringside judges ruled in favor of her opponent, leading to a 0–3 decision. The ringside judges were Braham Mohamad of Tunisia, Albino Foti of Italy, and Mariusz Josef Gorny of Poland.<ref>{{cite news|first1=|title=Mary Kom in final, Sarita Devi robbed of win at Asian Games|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-09-30/news/54475143_1_asian-games-l-sarita-devi-incheon|accessdate=1 October 2014|publisher=The Economic Times|date=30 September 2014}}</ref> The decision, which drew huge criticism, left Sarita Devi in a state of shock and she was seen weeping inconsolably.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: Boxer Sarita Devi refuses bronze after controversial decision|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/boxer-sarita-devi-refuses-asian-games-bronze-after-controversial-decision/1/393674.html|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=India Today|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> [[Indian Olympic Association]] (IOA) office-bearers chose not to involve themselves with the situation, leaving Sarita Devi and her husband Thoiba Singh to lodge the protests by themselves.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shameful: Sarita borrows appeal money from journalist as IOA officials sneak out|url=http://www.firstpost.com/sports/shameful-sarita-borrows-appeal-money-journalist-ioa-officials-sneak-away-1738345.html|accessdate=1 October 2014|publisher=F.Sports|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> They were unable to pay the [[United States dollar|USD$]]500 fee to lodge an official protest against [[International Boxing Association (amateur)|AIBA]] until Sarita's coach Lenin Meitei and an Indian journalist paid the amount on their behalf.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vasavda|first1=Mihir|title=Asian Games 2014: As Sarita Devi borrows to pay $500 as fee for lodging protest, IOA officials look other way|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/as-sarita-borrows-to-pay-500-as-fee-for-lodging-protest-ioa-officials-look-other-way/|accessdate=1 October 2014|publisher=The India Express|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> Sarita Devi stunned officials and spectators by refusing to accept the bronze medal during the medal ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games 2014: Boxer L Sarita Devi refuses to accept bronze medal; Sports Ministry to seek report from IOA|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-asian-games-2014-boxer-l-sarita-devi-refuses-to-accept-bronze-medal-sports-ministry-to-seek-report-from-ioa-2022841|accessdate=1 October 2014|agency=Zee Media Bureau/PTI|publisher=dna|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> Devi initially took her bronze medal and placed it around Park Jina's neck. After reluctantly receiving her medal back from Park Jina, Devi left the medal on the podium after the conclusion of the ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=What exactly happened? How Sarita Devi refused her boxing bronze medal|url=http://www.firstpost.com/sports/minute-minute-account-sarita-devis-refusal-accept-medal-asian-games-1738931.html|accessdate=1 October 2014|publisher=F.Sports|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> In interviews following the incident, Sarita Devi stated, "It was a protest for all the sportsmen and women of the world against injustice in sport". She also criticized Indian officials by stating, "It has been 24 hours and not one official has come to speak with me and ask me if I am fine. They just come here to take photos with medalists and nothing else."<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: I protested against injustice in sport, inconsolable Sarita Devi says|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tournaments/asian-games-2014/india-at-incheon/Asian-Games-I-protested-against-injustice-in-sport-inconsolable-Sarita-Devi-says/articleshow/44006082.cms|accessdate=1 October 2014|agency=AFP|publisher=The Times of India|date=1 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Chakravarty|first1=Shubhodeep|title=Sarita Devi May be Punished for Returning Asian Games Medal|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/asian-games-2014/news/230742-sarita-devi-may-be-punished-for-returning-asian-games-medal|accessdate=1 October 2014|publisher=NDTV Sports|date=3 October 2014}}</ref> AIBA opened disciplinary proceedings against Sarita for returning her medal and Adille Sumariwalla, the head of the Indian Mission, criticized Sarita Devi for her behavior.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: Some in Indian team not happy with Sarita Devi's emotional outburst|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tournaments/asian-games-2014/india-at-incheon/Asian-Games-Some-in-Indian-team-not-happy-with-Sarita-Devis-emotional-outburst/articleshow/44017525.cms|accessdate=1 October 2014|agency=PTI|publisher=The Times of India|date=1 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Boxer Sarita Devi faces AIBA probe for returning medal|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tournaments/asian-games-2014/india-at-incheon/Boxer-Sarita-Devi-faces-AIBA-probe-for-returning-medal/articleshow/44010279.cms|accessdate=1 October 2014|agency=PTI|publisher=The Times of India|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> The following day, Sarita Devi offered an unconditional apology to AIBA for her emotional outbreak during the medal ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sarita Devi apologises to AIBA for refusing medal|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/sports-news/asiangames2014/boxer-sarita-devi-apologises-to-aiba-for-refusing-to-accept-asian-games-medal/article1-1271242.aspx|accessdate=3 October 2014|agency=Reuters|publisher=hindustan times|date=3 October 2014}}</ref> She also expressed regret for her actions at the [[Olympic Council of Asia]] (OCA) hearing and the governing body reinstated Sarita Devi's bronze medal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Olympic Council of Asia re-instates L Sarita Devi’s bronze medal|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/olympic-council-of-asia-re-instates-l-sarita-devis-bronze-medal/|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=The Indian Express|date=2 October 2014}}</ref>
Shortly after Sarita Devi's controversial loss, Mongolian boxer [[Nyambayaryn Tögstsogt]] lost a controversial bout against South Korean Ham Sang-myeong in the 56 kg category. Nyambayar stayed in the ring for 5 minutes, protesting the results. The referees were booed by the crowd, and several Mongolian coaches arranged for a protest to be held.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hicks|first1=Daniel|last2=France-Presse|first2=Agence|title=Scuffles, protest over boxing decisions|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/sports/10/01/14/scuffles-protest-over-boxing-decisions|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=ABS-CBN News.com|date=1 October 2014}}</ref>
In men's 49 kg, India's [[Devendro Singh]] dubiously lost 0–3 in his quarterfinal bout against South Korea's [[Shin Jong-hun]], despite out-punching his opponent in all three rounds. Singh's trainer Blas Iglesias Fernandes of Cuba said, "I wish these judges could be sacked... I suppose the only ones who thought the Korean had won were the judges."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Masand|first1=Ajai|title=Asiad: Dodgy judging knocks out Sarita, Devendro|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/sports-news/asiangames2014/proud-mary-kom-keeps-on-rolling-eyes-asian-games-gold/article1-1270019.aspx|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=hindustan times|date=30 September 2014}}</ref>
In men's 52 kg, the [[Association of Boxing Alliances in the Philippines]] (ABAP) executive director Ed Picson was close to filing a protest against the decision in the match between Filipino boxer Ian Clark Bautista and his Korean opponent Choe Sang-don. Instead, he wrote a letter to Asian Games boxing tournament supervisor David Francis to seek a review of the questionable fights including this fight.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henson|first1=Joaquin|title=Boxing trend ‘worrisome’ in Incheon|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2014/09/29/1374380/boxing-trend-worrisome-incheon|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=29 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Terrado|first1=Reuben|title=Philippines seeks review of 'questionable' Asiad results after controversial Bautista loss|url=http://www.spin.ph/boxing/news/abap-ian-clark-bautista-loss-korea-sangdon-choe-boxing-asian-games-2014|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=Sports Interactive Network Philippines|date=29 September 2014}}</ref>
Picson later criticized the judging in three additional fights involving Filipino boxers. In the light flyweight round of 16, [[Mark Anthony Barriga]] lost to South Korea’s Shin Jong-hun by unanimous decision. In the bantamweight semifinal bout, Mario Fernandez lost to China's [[Zhang Jiawei]] despite a better showing in the final two rounds. In the middleweight semifinal bout, Wilfredo Lopez lost to Jordan's Odai Riyad Adel Alhindawi in a split 2–1 decision. The ABAP executive expressed frustration in the results of all three matches stating, "I would concede that they were pretty close fights but, that said, we won them."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hicks|first1=Daniel|title=Filipino boxing boss slams 'hometown' wins|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/381950/sports/boxing/asian-games-filipino-boxing-boss-slams-hometown-wins|accessdate=3 October 2014|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=GMA News|date=3 October 2014}}</ref>
In women's 57 kg, Thai boxer Sopida Satumrum lost a highly contentious decision to China's Si Haijuan. Two of the three judges scored a 38–38 draw while the third judge ruled 39–37 in favor of the Thai.<ref name=Sopida2>{{cite news|last1=Thongsombat|first1=Kittipong|title=Thailand left fuming after Sopida defeat|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/sports/434675/thailand-left-fuming-after-sopida-defeat|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=Bangkok Post|date=28 September 2014}}</ref> Under AIBA guidelines, the bout was declared a draw and the decision was deferred to a panel of five judges, which requires a majority decision. The five judges declared Si the winner of the bout.<ref name=Sopida>{{cite news|title=Sopida felled by highly contentious decision|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/sports/Sopida-felled-by-highly-contentious-decision-30244300.html|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=The Nation|date=28 September 2014}}</ref> Satumrum burst into tears after the result was announced and stated, "this is very cruel to me because I did much better than my opponent. I am 100% sure that I won."<ref name=Sopida2/><ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: Indian boxer facing action over medal snub|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/165338/asian-games-indian-boxer-facing-action-over-medal-snub|accessdate=3 October 2014|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Inquirer.net|date=2 October 2014}}</ref> Thai officials filed an official protest but organizers dismissed it saying the decision is beyond contention.<ref name=Sopida/>
===Men's football=== [[Worawi Makudi]], the president of [[Football Association of Thailand]], criticized the referees for making mistakes during the semi-final match between South Korea and Thailand. Coach [[Kiatisuk Senamuang]] voiced displeasure about the penalty kick awarded to South Korea following a foul outside the penalty area, which directly led to its second goal at the 45+1' minute mark.<ref>{{cite web|title=Football – Men's Semifinal 1 |url=http://www.incheon2014ag.org/Sports/FB/Result?RSC=FBM400201&lang=en |website=Incheon2014ag.org |accessdate=4 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141002082944/http://www.incheon2014ag.org/Sports/FB/Result?RSC=FBM400201&lang=en |archivedate= 2 October 2014 |df= }}</ref> Controversy continued as a South Korean defender used his arm to block the movement of the ball twice inside South Korea's penalty area. No call was not made on the handballs. South Korea won the match 2–0. Makudi stated that he would take the matter to the [[Asian Football Confederation]] but no official protest was lodged as of 4 October, the conclusion of the Games.<ref name=thenation/><ref name=wrestling/>
===Men's 71 kg Greco-Roman wrestling=== Iranian wrestler [[Saeid Abdevali]] had defeated South Korean wrestler [[Jung Ji-hyun]] in the semifinal of men's 71 kg Greco-Roman event. The winner was declared to be Abdevali, but the Korean officials violently protested the result following which Jung Ji-hyun was declared the winner.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wrestler Abdevali Hurt by Unjust Exit from Asian Games|url=http://www.tasnimnews.com/English/Home/Single/514589|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=Tasnim News Agency|date=30 September 2014}}</ref> Jung Ji-hyun went on to win the gold medal, while Abdevali was forced to settle for bronze.<ref name=wrestling>{{cite news|title=Asian Games: Controversy taints home team victories|url=http://www.koreatimesus.com/asian-games-controversy-taints-home-team-victories/|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=The Korea Times|date=1 October 2014}}</ref>
==Doping== Some 1,920 samples from 1,600 athletes were tested during the Games. Six athletes tested positive for banned substances and were sent home from the Games.<ref name=doping/>
On 14 September, five days before the opening ceremony, Tajikistan footballer Khurshed Beknazarov tested positive for [[methylhexanamine]]. He was subsequently suspended from all football activity for 30 days.<ref>{{cite news|title=AFC suspends Tajikistan footballer for doping at Asiad|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/sports-news/asiangames2014/afc-suspends-tajikistan-footballer-for-doping-at-asiad/article1-1268093.aspx|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=hindustan times|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> On 25 September, Cambodian soft tennis player Yi Sophany was found positive for [[sibutramine]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cambodian athlete expelled for doping at Asian Games|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/sports/article/cambodian-athlete-expelled-for-doping-at-asian-games|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=Malaysian Insider|date=25 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Two more athletes fail doping tests at Asian Games|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/sports-news/asiangames2014/two-more-athletes-fail-doping-tests-at-asian-games/article1-1268094.aspx|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=hindustan times|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> Sophany suspected that [[Sting Energy Drink|Sting]], her favorite energy drink may have been the cause of her positive doping test results. The doping committee informed her that sibutramine can be found on energy drinks.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sony|first1=Ouch|last2=Wright|first2=George|title=Disqualified Athlete Blames Energy Drink|url=http://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/disqualified-athlete-blames-energy-drink-68737/|accessdate=6 October 2014|work=The Cambodia Daily|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> On 30 September, Malaysian wushu gold medalist Tai Cheau Xuen also tested positive for sibutramine. She was stripped of her gold medal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Malaysian gold medalist kicked out of Asian Games for doping (updated)|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/xinhua-news-agency/140930/malaysian-gold-medalist-kicked-out-asian-games-doping-update|accessdate=30 September 2014|agency=Xinhua New Agency|publisher=globalpost|date=30 September 2014}}</ref> Malaysian officials appealed against the disqualification but the appeal was dismissed by the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] (CAS).<ref>{{cite news|title=Malaysia to appeal gold medalist expulsion - Khairy|url=http://english.astroawani.com/news/show/malaysia-to-appeal-gold-medalist-expulsion-khairy-45060|accessdate=30 September 2014|publisher=Astro Awani|date=30 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Malaysia lose appeal against doping failure|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/25173198/malaysia-lose-appeal-against-doping-failure/|accessdate=3 October 2014|agency=AFP|publisher=Yahoo! 7 News|date=2 October 2014}}</ref> The same day, Iraqi weightlifter Mohammed al Aifuri tested for positive for [[etiocholanolone]] and [[androsterone]]. It was his second failed drug test in six years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games 2014: Weightlifter from Iraq caught doping|url=http://www.cricketcountry.com/asian-games-2014/asian-games-2014-weightlifter-from-iraq-caught-doping-194010|accessdate=30 September 2014|publisher=The Cricket Country|date=30 September 2014}}</ref> He faces a ban by the [[International Weightlifting Federation]] (IWF), which had banned him once before in 2008 for taking [[metandienone]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Iraqi weightlifter caught doping at Asiad|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tournaments/asian-games-2014/news/Iraqi-weightlifter-caught-doping-at-Asiad/articleshow/43909834.cms|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=The Times of India|date=30 September 2014}}</ref> On 1 October, Syrian karate fighter Nour-Aldin al-Kurdi tested positive for [[clenbuterol]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=France-Presse|first1=Agence|title=Track, Medal, Doping Rows Cloud Asian Games|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/asian-games-2014/news/230756-track-medal-doping-rows-cloud-asian-games|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher=NDTV Sports|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> On 3 October, Chinese hammer thrower [[Zhang Wenxiu]] became the second gold medalist to be stripped of their gold medal after testing positive for [[zeranol]].<ref name=doping>{{cite news|last1=Rutherford|first1=Peter|last2=Chakraborty|first2=Amlan|title=Games-China's hammer champion Zhang tests positive|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-2779263/Games-Chinese-hammer-gold-medallist-Zhang-tests-positive.html|accessdate=3 October 2014|agency=Reuters|publisher=Mail Online|date=3 October 2014}}</ref>
However, on 6 May 2015, Zhang's gold medal was returned after further testing performed by independent specialists that the presence zeranol was the consequence of the consumption of contaminated food.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mulvenney|first1=Nick|last2=Ransom|first2=Ian|title=Chinese hammer thrower Wang gets Asian Games gold returned|url=http://www.euronews.com/sport/3013619-chinese-hammer-thrower-wang-gets-asian-games-gold-returned/|accessdate=16 May 2015|publisher=euronews|date=6 May 2015}}</ref>
==Other==
===Asian Games flame===
Due to technical reasons, the Asian Games flame went out temporarily.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asian Games flame goes out due to technical reasons|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/asian-games-flame-goes-out-due-to-technical-reasons/500900-5-23.html|accessdate=27 September 2014|publisher=IBN Live}}</ref>

'''Contempt of the Sovereign''' (also called '''contempt of statute''') was an ancient doctrine in [[English law]] dating from medieval times, and now obsolete. It referred to the notion that if somebody disobeyed an [[Act of Parliament]], but the Act did not say what the penalty was or how the Act was to be enforced, then that person was guilty of a criminal offence under [[common law]] (although the crime itself was not called contempt). This doctrine was based on the idea that an Act of Parliament was an expression of the Sovereign's will, enacted with the "advice and consent" of Parliament. In modern legislation and jurisprudence it has become the rule that contravening a statute is not a crime unless the statute expressly says so in clear terms, and so the doctrine has long since lapsed. However the law does still exist, and the last time it was used was in 1840.<ref>[[Halsbury's Laws of England]], 5th edition, volume 25, paragraph 362</ref>
Contempt of the Sovereign is not to be confused with [[lèse majesté]].
==References== {{reflist}} * [[Archbold Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice]] (2010) 1-6

[[File:ARC 525689 111-B-1484 05-1326a.gif|thumb|Edward P. Doherty (1838-1897)]] '''Edward Paul Doherty''' (September 26, 1838 – April 3, 1897) was an Irish-Canadian-American [[American Civil War|U.S. Civil War]] officer who formed and led the detachment of soldiers that captured and killed [[John Wilkes Booth]], the assassin of [[President of the United States|United States President]] [[Abraham Lincoln]], in a [[Virginia]] barn on April 26, 1865, twelve days after Lincoln was fatally shot.
==Early life and service in the American Civil War== Doherty was born September 26, 1838 in [[Wickham, Quebec|Wickham]], [[Canada East]], to immigrant parents from [[Sligo]], [[Ireland]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Parker |first=Alan |date=May 4, 2015 |title=The Canadian Who Captured Abraham Lincoln’s Assassin |url=http://blogs.canoe.com/parker/news/the-canadian-who-captured-abraham-lincolns-assassin |newspaper=Toronto Sun |access-date=October 8, 2015}}</ref> His birth year has long been incorrectly believed to have been 1840, however it was clearly recorded as 1838 in Wickham's parish records.<ref>"Québec, registres paroissiaux catholiques, 1621-1979," database with images, FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-1942-28000-5937-33?cc=1321742 : accessed 18 December 2015), Drummondville > Saint-Frédéric-de-Drummondville > Index 1816-1876 Baptêmes, mariages, sépultures 1816-1844 > image 444 of 613; Catholic Church parishes, Quebec.</ref>
He came to [[New York (state)|New York]] in 1860 where he was living when the [[American Civil War]] broke out. He enlisted in a 90-day militia unit and was assigned as a [[Private (rank)|Private]] to Company A of the [[71st Infantry Regiment (New York)|71st New York Volunteers]] on April 20, 1861. Assigned to [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] [[Ambrose Burnside|Ambrose Burnside's]] 2nd Brigade of [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[David Hunter|David Hunter's]] 2nd Division, he was captured by the [[Confederate States Army|Confederates]] during the [[First Battle of Bull Run]], the first major land battle of the [[American Civil War]], fought on July 21, 1861, near [[Manassas, Virginia|Manassas]], [[Virginia]]. While a prisoner, he made a daring escape. Ultimately, the [[71st Infantry Regiment (New York)|71st Regiment]], along with Doherty, mustered out on August 9, 1861.
Doherty went on to become a [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] in the Corcoran Legion, formed by fellow prisoner at the [[First Battle of Bull Run]], [[Irish American|Irish-American]] [[General officer|General]] [[Michael Corcoran]], who was a close confidant of [[Abraham Lincoln]]. Doherty served for two years, before being appointed [[Lieutenant|First Lieutenant]] in the [[16th Regiment New York Volunteer Cavalry|16th New York Cavalry]] on September 12, 1863. The regiment was assigned to the defense of [[Washington, D.C.]] for the duration of the war, where Doherty distinguished himself as an officer.
==Pursuit and capture of John Wilkes Booth== On April 24, 1865, 10 days after the assassination of [[Abraham Lincoln]], Acting Assistant Adjunct General A. R. Sewell sent an order to the Commander of the 16th New York Cavalry, Captain Joseph Schneider, to assign a reliable and discreet commissioned officer with 25 men to report to Colonel L. C. Baker at once. Captain Schneider then chose Lieutenant Edward Doherty to lead the group<ref><Official records for the Union And Confederate Armies, 1861-1865, Series I: Formal reports... Chapter LVIIL pages 1317-1318</ref> and Doherty reported to [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] [[Lafayette C. Baker]], Agent of the [[United States Department of War|Department of War]]. Doherty and his men were to hunt down [[John Wilkes Booth]] and any co-conspirators. Two days later, the men of the 16th NY Cavalry Regiment, accompanied by two detectives of the intelligence service, Luther Baker, cousin of [[Lafayette C. Baker]], and [[Everton Conger|Everton J. Conger]], caught up with Booth and his accomplice [[David E. Herold]] in a tobacco barn near [[Port Royal, Virginia|Port Royal]], [[Virginia]] owned by [[Richard H. Garrett]]. With the barn surrounded, Doherty called upon Booth to surrender, but he refused and threatened to shoot anyone who entered. His accomplice relented and as he surrendered to Doherty, [[Sergeant#United States|Sergeant]] [[Boston Corbett]] fatally shot Booth through a crack in the side of the barn, as the assassin had been aiming to fire at either Doherty or Herold. Doherty stated that "the bullet struck Booth in the back of the head, about an inch below the spot where his shot had entered the head of Mr. Lincoln." Booth's [[spinal cord]] was severed, and he died two hours later.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Death of John Wilkes Booth, 1865|url=http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/booth.htm|publisher=Eyewitness to History/Ibis Communications|accessdate=August 16, 2012}} (Quoting Lieutenant Edward Doherty, officer in charge of the soldiers who captured Booth)</ref> Doherty and the men of his regiment returned to [[Washington, D.C.]] on April 27, 1865 with Booth's body.
==Military career after Abraham Lincoln's assassination== For his service in the capture of [[Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln's]] assassin, Doherty was promoted to [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] and given a US$5,250 reward, while remaining in the cavalry. The [[16th Regiment New York Volunteer Cavalry|16th New York Cavalry]] was merged with the [[13th Regiment New York Volunteer Cavalry|13th New York Cavalry]] forming the [[3rd Regiment New York Provisional Cavalry]] on June 23, 1865, which was then mustered out on September 21, 1865. Seven months later, Doherty joined the regular cavalry and was assigned to the [[5th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|5th Regular Cavalry]] as a [[Lieutenant|Second Lieutenant]] on April 19, 1866. He was promoted to [[Lieutenant|First Lieutenant]] on March 1, 1867 in the [[1st Cavalry Division (United States)|1st Cavalry]] and remained in the regular army until mustering out on December 27, 1870. During his last years in the military, he served some time under [[General officer|General]] [[George Meade]] as [[Inspector General]] of the Department of Georgia, which had been created by the military in 1865 as part of the [[Third Military District]] during the post-war [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]] period.
==Post-military life and death== [[File:Epdoherty-gravesite-section1-062803.jpg|thumb|Edward P. Doherty's tombstone (note the error in the birth year)]] In 1871, after resigning from the [[United States Army]], Doherty went into business in [[New Orleans]]. Having returned to [[New York City]] in 1886, he was appointed Inspector of Street Pavings, a position which he held from 1888 until his death on the morning of April 3, 1897. He was Past Commander of Veteran Post Number 436, G. A. R.; as well as a member of the [[71st Infantry Regiment (New York)|71st Regiment]] Veterans and also of the Press Veterans. He served twice as [[Grand Marshal]] in [[Memorial Day]] celebrations. Doherty succumbed to heart disease, dying in his home at 533 West 144th Street, the funeral was held on April 5, 1897 at the Church of St. Charles Boromeo church, then located at 132nd Street and Seventh Avenue. He is buried in Section 1 of [[Arlington National Cemetery]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]. His tombstone reads: "Commanded detachment of [[16th Regiment New York Volunteer Cavalry|16th N.Y. Cavalry]] which captured President [[Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln's]] assassin April 26, 1865."

A '''formal system''' is used to infer theorems from axioms according to a set of rules. These rules used to carry out the inference of theorems from axioms are known as the '''logical calculus''' of the formal system. A formal system may represent a well-defined [[abstraction|system of abstract thought]]. Spinoza's ''[[Ethics (Spinoza)|Ethics]]'' imitates the form of Euclid's ''Elements''. Spinoza employed Euclidean elements such as "[[axiom]]s" or "[[Primitive notion|primitive truths]]", [[Rule of inference|rules of inferences]], etc., so that a calculus can be built using these.
Some theorists{{which|date=January 2017}} use the term ''formalism'' as a rough synonym for ''formal system'', but the term is also used to refer to a particular style{{which|date=January 2017}} of [[notation]], for example, [[Paul Dirac]]'s [[bra–ket notation]].
==Background==
Each formal system uses primitive [[Symbol (formal)|symbols]] (which collectively form an [[Alphabet (computer science)|alphabet]]) to finitely construct a [[formal language]] from a set of [[axiom]]s through inferential [[rules of formation]].
The system thus consists of valid formulas built up through finite combinations of the primitive symbols—combinations that are formed from the axioms in accordance with the stated rules.<ref>Encyclopædia Britannica, [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9034889/formal-system Formal system] definition, 2007.</ref>
More formally, this can be expressed as the following:
# A finite set of symbols, known as the alphabet, which concatenate formulas, so that a formula is just a finite string of symbols taken from the alphabet. # A [[Formal grammar|grammar]] consisting of rules to form formulas from simpler formulas. A formula is said to be [[well-formed formula|well-formed]] if it can formed using the rules of the formal grammar. It is often required that there be a decision procedure for deciding whether a formula is well-formed. # A set of axioms, or [[axiom schema]]ta, consisting of well-formed formulas. # A set of [[rule of inference|inference rules]]. A well-formed formula that can be inferred from the axioms is known as a theorem of the formal system.
===Recursive===
A formal system is said to be [[Recursive set|recursive]] (i.e. effective) or recursively enumerable if the set of axioms and the set of inference rules are [[decidable set]]s or [[recursively enumerable set|semidecidable sets]], respectively.
===Inference and entailment===
The [[entailment]] of the system by its logical foundation is what distinguishes a formal system from others which may have some basis in an abstract model. Often the formal system will be the basis for or even identified with a larger theory or field (e.g. [[Euclidean geometry]]) consistent with the usage in modern mathematics such as [[model theory]].{{what|reason=This section doesn't really do a group job stating what an entailment actually is.|date=September 2017}}
==== Formal language ==== {{Main|Formal language|formal grammar}}
A [[formal language]] is a language that is defined by a formal system. Like languages in [[linguistics]], formal languages generally have two aspects:
* the [[syntax]] of a language is what the language looks like (more formally: the set of possible expressions that are valid utterances in the language) studied in [[formal language theory]] * the [[semantics]] of a language are what the utterances of the language mean (which is formalized in various ways, depending on the type of language in question)
In [[computer science]] and [[linguistics]] a formal grammar is a precise description of a [[formal language]]: a [[set (mathematics)|set]] of [[String (computer science)|strings]]. The two main categories of formal grammar are that of [[generative grammar]]s, which are sets of rules for how strings in a language can be generated, and that of [[analytic grammar]]s (or reductive grammar,<ref>Reductive grammar: (''computer science'') A set of syntactic rules for the analysis of strings to determine whether the strings exist in a language. {{cite web|url=http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/reductive+grammar|title=Sci-Tech Dictionary McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms|publisher=McGraw-Hill|edition=6th}}{{unreliable source?|date=February 2015}} About the Author Compiled by The Editors of the McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Science & Technology (New York, NY) an in-house staff who represents the cutting-edge of skill, knowledge, and innovation in science publishing. [https://www.amazon.com/McGraw-Hill-Dictionary-Scientific-Technical-Terms/dp/007042313X#productDescription_secondary_view_pageState_1423332836958]</ref><ref> "There are two classes of formal-language definition compiler-writing schemes. The productive [[formal grammar|grammar]] approach is the most common. A productive grammar consists primarrly of a set of rules that describe a method of generating all possible strings of the language. The reductive or [[formal grammar#Analytic grammars|analytical grammar]] technique states a set of rules that describe a method of analyzing any string of characters and deciding whether that string is in the language." {{cite web|url=http://bitsavers.informatik.uni-stuttgart.de/pdf/sri/arc/rulifson/A_Tree_Meta_For_The_XDS_940_Appendix_D_Apr68.pdf|title='''The TREE-META Compiler-Compiler System: A Meta Compiler System for the Univac 1108 and General Electric 645''', University of Utah Technical Report RADC-TR-69-83. C. Stephen Carr, David A. Luther, Sherian Erdmann |accessdate=5 January 2015}} </ref>) which are sets of rules for how a string can be analyzed to determine whether it is a member of the language. In short, an analytic grammar describes how to ''recognize'' when strings are members in the set, whereas a generative grammar describes how to ''write'' only those strings in the set.
==== Logical system ==== A ''logical system'' or, for short, a ''logic'', is a formal system together with its [[Semantics of logic|semantics]],{{disputed-inline|No semantics needed|date=June 2015}}. According to [[Model theory|model-theoretic]] [[interpretation (logic)|interpretation]], the semantics of a logical system describe whether a well-formed formula is satisfied by a given structure. A structure that satisfies all the axioms of the formal system is known as a model of the logical system. A logical system is [[Soundness|sound]] if each well-formed formula that can be inferred from the axioms is satisfied by every model of the logical system. Conversely, a logic system is [[Completeness (logic)|complete]] if each well-formed formula that is satisfied by every model of the logical system can be inferred from the axioms.
==== Deductive inference ==== A ''deductive system'', also called a '''deductive apparatus''', consists of the [[axiom]]s (or [[axiom schema]]ta) and [[rules of inference]] that can be used to [[formal proof|derive]] [[theorem]]s of the system.<ref>Hunter, Geoffrey, Metalogic: An Introduction to the Metatheory of Standard First-Order Logic, University of California Pres, 1971</ref>
Such deductive systems preserve [[deductive reasoning|deductive]] qualities in the [[formula (mathematical logic)|formula]]s that are expressed in the system. Usually the quality we are concerned with is [[truth]] as opposed to falsehood. However, other [[modal logic|modalities]], such as [[Theory of justification|justification]] or [[belief]] may be preserved instead.
In order to sustain its deductive integrity, a ''deductive apparatus'' must be definable without reference to any [[intended interpretation]] of the language. The aim is to ensure that each line of a [[Mathematical proof|derivation]] is merely a [[syntactic consequence]] of the lines that precede it. There should be no element of any [[Interpretation (logic)|interpretation]] of the language that gets involved with the deductive nature of the system.
==History== Early logic systems includes Indian logic of [[Pāṇini]], syllogistic logic of Aristotle, propositional logic of Stoicism,￼￼ and Chinese logic of [[Gongsun Long]] (c. 325–250 BCE) . In recent times, contributors include [[George Boole]], [[Augustus De Morgan]], and [[Gottlob Frege]]. [[Mathematical logic]] was developed in 19th century [[Europe]].
===Formalism=== {{main|Mathematical formalism}}
====Hilbert's program==== {{main|Hilbert's program}}
[[David Hilbert]] instigated a formalist movement that was eventually tempered by [[Gödel's incompleteness theorems]].
{{expand section|date=January 2017}}
===QED manifesto=== {{main|QED manifesto}}
The QED manifesto represented a subsequent unsuccessful effort at formalization of known mathematics.
{{expand section|date=January 2017}}
== Examples == {{main|List of formal systems}}
Examples of formal systems include:
* [[Axiomatic system]] * [[Formal ethics]] * [[Lambda calculus]] * [[Proof calculus]]
{{expand section|date=January 2017}}
==Variants==
The following systems are variations of formal systems{{clarify|date=January 2017}}.
=== Proof system === {{Main|Proof system|Formal proof}} Formal proofs are sequences of [[well-formed formula]]s (or wff for short). For a wff to qualify as part of a proof, it might either be an [[axiom]] or be the product of applying an inference rule on previous wffs in the proof sequence. The last wff in the sequence is recognized as a [[Theorem#Theorems in logic|theorem]].
The point of view that generating formal proofs is all there is to mathematics is often called ''[[Philosophy of mathematics#Formalism|formalism]]''. [[David Hilbert]] founded [[metamathematics]] as a discipline for discussing formal systems. Any language that one uses to talk about a formal system is called a ''[[metalanguage]]''. The metalanguage may be a natural language, or it may be partially formalized itself, but it is generally less completely formalized than the formal language component of the formal system under examination, which is then called the ''[[object language]]'', that is, the object of the discussion in question.
Once a formal system is given, one can define the set of theorems which can be proved inside the formal system. This set consists of all wffs for which there is a proof. Thus all axioms are considered theorems. Unlike the grammar for wffs, there is no guarantee that there will be a [[decidability (logic)|decision procedure]] for deciding whether a given wff is a theorem or not. The notion of ''theorem'' just defined should not be confused with ''theorems about the formal system'', which, in order to avoid confusion, are usually called [[metatheorem]]s.

{{Other uses|Glitterbomb (disambiguation){{!}}Glitterbomb}} [[File:Vermin Supreme glitterbombs Randall Terry (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Vermin Supreme]] glitter bombs [[Randall Terry]] during a Democratic Party presidential debate at [[Saint Anselm College]].]] '''Glitter bombing''' is an act of [[protest]] in which activists throw [[glitter]] on people at public events.<ref name="vinciguerra">Vinciguerra, Thomas (August 27, 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/opinion/sunday/glitter-a-kinder-gentler-prank.html Glittering Rage.] ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> Glitter bombers have frequently been motivated by, though not limited to, their targets' rape apologism or opposition to [[same-sex marriage]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Moody|first=Chris|title=‘Glitter advocates’ plot their next victim|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/yblog_theticket/20110620/pl_yblog_theticket/glitter-advocates-plot-their-next-victim|accessdate=October 7, 2011|newspaper=Yahoo! News|date=June 20, 2011}}</ref>
Some legal officials argue glitter bombing is technically [[assault]] and [[battery (crime)|battery]]. It is possible for glitter to enter the eyes or nose and cause damage to the [[cornea]] or other soft tissues potentially irritating them or leading to infection,<ref>{{cite news|last=Kurtz|first=Judy|title=Eye doctor warns of dangers of political protest on gay marriage|url=http://thehill.com/capital-living/in-the-know/209573-eye-doctor-warns-of-dangers-of-political-protest-on-gay-marriage-|newspaper=The Hill|date=February 8, 2012}}</ref> depending on the size of the glitter. Whether a prosecutor would pursue the charges depends on a number of factors.<ref>{{cite news|last=van der Pool|first=Lisa|title=All that glitters is not gold, in the eyes of legal system|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/print-edition/2011/09/02/all-that-glitters-is-not-gold-in-the.html|accessdate=November 21, 2011|newspaper=Boston Business Journal|date=September 2, 2011}}</ref>
==Targets== {|class="wikitable sortable" |-valign=bottom ! Recipient ! Date ! Location ! class="unsortable"|Details |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Newt Gingrich.jpg|75px]] [[Newt Gingrich]] | May 17, 2011 | [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]] | The former [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House of Representatives]] and his wife [[Callista Gingrich|Callista]] were showered with glitter at a book signing. Nick Espinosa dumped a full box of glitter on them, shouting "Stop the hate!" and "Feel the rainbow, Newt!"<ref>{{cite news|title=US presidential candidate Newt Gingrich showered in glitter|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13447526|accessdate=October 7, 2011|publisher=BBC News|date=May 18, 2011}}</ref><ref name=pawlenty>{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Christine|title=Protesters glitter bomb GOP candidate Tim Pawlenty|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/06/17/2011-06-17_protesters_glitter_bomb_gop_candidate_tim_pawlenty.html|accessdate=October 7, 2011|newspaper=Daily News|date=June 17, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Espinosa|first=Nick|title=The Glitter Bomber Speaks: A New Generation Feels the Rainbow|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nick-espinosa/the-glitter-bomber-speaks_b_983331.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=October 3, 2011}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Tim Pawlenty by Gage Skidmore.jpg|75px]] [[Tim Pawlenty]] | June 16, 2011 | [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, was showered with glitter and pink feathers by Nancy Mancias and Chelsea Byers, two members of the anti-war coalition [[Code Pink|CODEPINK]]. He was targeted at a book signing in [[San Francisco]], with the perpetrators stating that Pawlenty's "homophobic attitude" and opposition to [[recognition of same-sex unions in Minnesota]] motivated them.<ref name=pawlenty /> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Michele Bachmann by Gage Skidmore 5.jpg|75px]] [[Michele Bachmann]] | June 18, 2011 | [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]] | Bachmann, a member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from Minnesota, was glitter bombed in Minneapolis by Rachel E. B. Lang with the support of the LGBT-interest organizations [[GetEQUAL]] and [[Children of Lesbians and Gays Everywhere|COLAGE]]. Lang was motivated by Bachmann's support for [[You Can Run But You Cannot Hide International|a ministry that opposes LGBT issues]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bachmann joins the glitteratti|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/national/politico/article/Bachmann-joins-the-glitteratti-1430181.php|accessdate=October 7, 2011|newspaper=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|date=June 18, 2011}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | Bachmann & Associates | July 21, 2011 | [[Lake Elmo, Minnesota]] | Michele Bachmann's husband Marcus Bachmann is a therapist whose clinical practices, in particular his practicing [[reparative therapy]] designed to change the sexual orientation of patients from homosexual to heterosexual, drew scrutiny during his wife's 2012 presidential campaign. Activists dressed as [[barbarian]]s (a reference to a comment by Marcus Bachmann analogizing homosexuality to barbarism) glitter bombed Bachmann & Associates' Minnesota office to protest the Bachmanns' stances on LGBT issues.<ref>{{cite news|last=Grindley|first=Lucas|title="Barbarians" Raid Marcus Bachmann's Office|url=http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2011/07/21/Barbarians_Raid_Marcus_Bachmann_s_Office/|accessdate=October 7, 2011|newspaper=The Advocate|date=July 21, 2011}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | Minnesota for Marriage | style="white-space: nowrap;"|September 4, 2011 | [[Falcon Heights, Minnesota]] | Minnesota for Marriage, an organization that favors passing a constitutional amendment disallowing same-sex marriage in Minnesota, was glitter bombed at the 2011 Minnesota State Fair by protesters opposed to the amendment.<ref>{{cite news|last=Buchta|first=Jim|title=Glitter rains down on group backing marriage amendment|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/129242748.html|accessdate=October 7, 2011|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=September 6, 2011}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Karl Rove.jpg|75px]] [[Karl Rove]] | October 7, 2011 | [[Bloomington, Minnesota]] | During a book signing, Rove was glitter bombed by Ben Egerman. No charges were filed.<ref name="rove paulsen">{{cite news|last=Michelson|first=Noah|title=Glitterati, LGBT+ Rights Activists, Glitter Bomb Karl Rove And Republican Minnesota Congressman Erik Paulsen|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/07/glitterati-glitter-bombs-paulsen_n_1000534.html|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=October 7, 2011}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Erikpaulsen.jpg|75px]] [[Erik Paulsen]] | October 7, 2011 | [[Bloomington, Minnesota]] | Congressman Erik Paulsen (R-MN) who was receiving a "Friend of the Family" award for his efforts to place a constitution amendment to ban marriages for same-sex couples on the ballot in Minnesota for 2012. Michael Cahil shouted "You're no friend to my family!" as he showered Paulsen with glitter.<ref name="rove paulsen"/> |- | rowspan="3" align=left nowrap | [[File:Dan Savage Provided.jpg|75px]] [[Dan Savage]] | November 1, 2011 | [[Eugene, Oregon]] | Savage was glitter bombed on November 1, 2011, at the University of Oregon, Eugene. The glitter bomber said they were a representative of the "Dan Savage Welcoming Committee" and that Savage was a "transphobe" as well as "racist and misogynist and a rape-apologist".<ref>{{cite web|last=Hill-Meyer |first=Tobi |url=http://www.bilerico.com/2011/11/dan_savage_gets_glitter_bombed_for_being_transphob.php |title=Dan Savage Gets Glitter Bombed for Being Transphobic |publisher=The Bilerico Project |date=November 2, 2011 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> |- | November 9, 2011 | [[Irvine, California]] | Savage was hit again on November 9, 2011, at a talk at the [[University of California, Irvine]], with one bomber saying Savage was transphobic.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hill-Meyer |first=Tobi |url=http://www.bilerico.com/2011/11/dan_savage_glittered_again_student_arrested.php |title=Dan Savage Glittered Again, Student Arrested |publisher=The Bilerico Project |date=November 14, 2011 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> |- | January 21, 2012 | |[[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] | Queer activists glitter bombed Dan Savage on January 21, 2012, on the way into his "[[It Gets Better]]" show at the Vogue Theatre in Vancouver. His response was "Oh no! Not again!" The group said the bombing was in response to "ableism, ageism, classism, misogyny, racism, rape-apologism, [[serophobia]], sizism, transphobia and, oh yeah, that column".<ref>{{cite web|last=Oommen |first=Isaac |url=http://vancouver.mediacoop.ca/photo/dan-savage-glitterbombed/9681 |title=Dan Savage Glitterbombed |publisher=Vancouver Media Co-op |date=January 21, 2012 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Randall Terry 2.jpg|75px]] [[Randall Terry]] | December 19, 2011 | [[Goffstown, New Hampshire]] | Terry was glitter bombed by fellow presidential candidate [[Vermin Supreme]] during a lesser-known candidates forum at [[Saint Anselm College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/talesfromthetrail/2011/12/20/in-new-hampshire-fringe-candidates-get-their-moment/|title=In New Hampshire, fringe candidates get their moment|date=December 20, 2011|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=December 21, 2011}}</ref> Vermin said that Jesus told him to turn Terry gay.<ref>{{cite news| first=Simón |last=Ríos |title=Lesser-known candidates bring colorful campaigns to St. Anselm |url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20111220/NEWS0605/712209967 |work=[[New Hampshire Union Leader]] |date=December 20, 2011 |accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref> |- | rowspan="2" align=left nowrap | [[File:Rick Santorum by Gage Skidmore.jpg|75px]] [[Rick Santorum]] | January 21, 2012 | [[Charleston, South Carolina]] | Santorum's first glitter bombing was at his South Carolina primary headquarters over the January 21–22 weekend of 2012. Occupy Charleston claimed credit for the incident. The protesters were forcibly removed after protesting [[Rick Santorum's views on homosexuality|Santorum's stance on LGBT+ rights]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/46106278 |title=Rick Santorum Gets Glitter Bombed, Again |publisher=MSNBC |date=January 24, 2012 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> |- | January 23, 2012 | [[Lady Lake, Florida]] | During a Florida presidential primary stop in [[Lady Lake, Florida]], he was showered by a glitter bomb from protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxorlando.com/dpp/news/local/012312-santorum-recipient-of-another-glitter-bomb |title=Santorum recipient of another 'glitter bomb' |publisher=Myfoxorlando.com |date=January 23, 2012 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Joe Lieberman official portrait.jpg|75px]] [[Joe Lieberman]] | January 28, 2012 | [[Washington, D.C.]] | Senator Lieberman was glitter bombed by protesters with [[Occupy D.C.]] when he attended the [[Alfalfa Club]]'s annual banquet.<ref>{{cite news|last=Morgenstern|first=Madeleine|title=Occupy DC Targets Exclusive Presidential Dinner, Sen. Lieberman Glitter-Bombed|url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/occupy-dc-targets-exclusive-presidential-dinner-sen-lieberman-glitter-bombed/|newspaper=The Blaze|date=January 29, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Mitt Romney by Gage Skidmore 6.jpg|75px]] [[Mitt Romney]] | February 1, 2012 | [[Eagan, Minnesota]] | Romney was glitter bombed at a rally in Eagan, Minnesota. His response was to smile and proclaim it was confetti for winning Florida.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-57369887-503544/mitt-romney-glitter-bombed-calls-it-confetti/|title=Mitt Romney glitter bombed, calls it confetti|publisher=CBS News|date=February 1, 2012 |accessdate=February 1, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Rick Santorum by Gage Skidmore.jpg|75px]] [[Rick Santorum]] | February 2, 2012 | [[Columbia, Missouri]] | Santorum was again glitter bombed while at a presidential primary campaign event that also featured [[Focus on the Family]] founder [[James Dobson]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/2012/feb/03/student-challenges-santorum-gay-marriage/ |title=Fulton, Columbia crowds hear Santorum's views |work=Columbia Tribune |date=February 4, 2012 |accessdate=February 5, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Ron Paul, official 109th Congress photo.jpg|75px]] [[Ron Paul]] | February 6, 2012 | [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]] | Ron Paul was glitter bombed at a rally in the [[Minneapolis Convention Center]] by a protester who shouted "Housing and health care are human rights not privileges!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2012/02/ron_paul_glitterbombed_at_minneapolis_convention_center_video.php |title=Ron Paul glitterbombed at Minneapolis Convention Center |publisher=blogs.citypages.com |date=February 6, 2012 |accessdate=February 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210110119/http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2012/02/ron_paul_glitterbombed_at_minneapolis_convention_center_video.php |archivedate=February 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Mitt Romney by Gage Skidmore 6.jpg|75px]] [[Mitt Romney]] | February 7, 2012 | [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] | Romney was glitter bombed again following a speech during the Colorado Primary. A protester attempted to glitter bomb Romney, but was quickly caught and removed by [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] agents, and he pleaded guilty to disturbing the peace in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web|author=04/13/2012 8:41 am Updated: 04/13/2012 9:01 am |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/13/mitt-romney-glitter-bomb-_n_1423082.html |title=Mitt Romney Glitter Bomb: Peter Smith Pleads Guilty To Disturbing The Peace For Glitter Bombing After Colo. Caucus (PHOTOS, VIDEO) |work=The Huffington Post |date=2012-04-13 |accessdate=2012-12-31}}</ref> |- | rowspan="2" align=left nowrap | [[File:Rick Santorum by Gage Skidmore.jpg|75px]] [[Rick Santorum]] | February 13, 2012 | [[Tacoma, Washington]] | During a presidential primary stop in [[Tacoma, Washington]], Santorum was covered in a "blizzard of glitter".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2012/02/14/santorum-in-tacoma-protesters-and-a-glitter-bomb/ |title=Santorum in Tacoma: Protesters and a Glitter Bomb |publisher=wsj.com |date=February 14, 2012 |accessdate=February 16, 2012}}</ref> |- | February 15, 2012 | [[Fargo, North Dakota]] | Santorum made a presidential primary stop in [[Fargo, North Dakota]], and was showered by a glitter bomb in front of a packed crowd at a Holiday Inn. He launched into his speech seemingly unfazed by the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/rosiegray/even-in-fargo-rick-santorum-cannot-escape-the-gli |title=Even In Fargo, Rick Santorum Cannot Escape The Glitter Bomb |publisher=buzzfeed.com |date=February 15, 2012 |accessdate=February 16, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Germaine Greer.jpg|75px]] [[Germaine Greer]] | March 14, 2012 | [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]] | Germaine Greer was glitter bombed at a [[book signing]] at the [[Embassy Theatre, Wellington|Embassy Theatre]] in Wellington, New Zealand. A group known as the Queer Avengers was responsible. They were protesting Greer's views on [[transsexualism]], which the group claims are [[Transphobia|transphobic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10792049 |title=Germaine Greer 'glitter bombed' by Queer Avengers |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |date=March 14, 2012 |accessdate=October 7, 2012}}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Lindsay Lohan at Cynthia Rowley.jpg|75px]] [[Lindsay Lohan]] | March 18, 2013 | [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | Lindsay Lohan and her media swarm were showered with gold glitter as she walked to the Los Angeles Court house on 18 March. The woman suspected of throwing the glitter was not arrested and there was no apparent motive.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ryot.org/this-lindsay-lohan-glitter-bomb-photo-is-the-best-glitter-bomb-photo-ever-and-its-not-even-close/103717 |title=This Lindsay Lohan glitter bomb photo is the best glitter bomb photo ever{{snd}}and it’s not even close |publisher=RYOT |date=March 8, 2013 }}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:George Galloway.jpg|75px]] [[George Galloway]] | November 22, 2016 | [[Aberdeen]], [[Scotland]] | George Galloway was covered in glitter as he attempted to give a talk to the [[University of Aberdeen]] Politics & International Relations Society. A group of students carried out the protest citing Galloway's alleged rape apologism and antisemitism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/watch-moment-george-galloway-is-9313971 |title=Watch moment George Galloway 'is attacked with glitter during scuffle with student protesters at university' |work=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=November 22, 2016 }}</ref> |- | align=left nowrap | [[File:Richard_B._Spencer_in_2016.jpg|75px]] [[Richard B. Spencer]] | April 9, 2017 | [[Washington, D.C.]] | Richard B. Spencer was glitter bombed while leading a protest against the [[2017 Shayrat missile strike]]. Counter-protesters called him a "Nazi snowflake" and glitter bombed him. It was unclear if anyone was arrested in relation to the glitter-bombing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/4130177/richard-spencer-attacked-alt-right-leader-just-punched-in-the-face-again-then-glitter-bombed/|title=Richard Spencer Attacked: Alt Right Leader Just Punched In The Face Again, Then Glitter Bombed|last=Francis|first=Nathan|work=[[Inquisitr]]|date=April 9, 2017|accessdate=April 9, 2017}}</ref> |}
==Postal glitter bombs== [[File:Glitter bomb envelope.jpg|thumb|Unwanted junk mail returned to sender as a glitter bomb]] Glitter bombs can be sent through the post, so that glitter falls from an envelope or is forcefully ejected from a larger, spring-loaded package when opened.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Towe|first1=Peter|title=Son sends dad spring-loaded glitter bomb|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/examviral/fun-times/son-sends-dad-spring-loaded-glitter-bomb-307574.html|website=Irish Examiner|accessdate=3 November 2016|date=18 January 2015}}</ref> In 2015, RuinDays.com began offering a service where an envelope containing loose glitter or spring-loaded glitter bombs could be sent anonymously to a victim.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McGinn|first1=Dave|title=Glitter bombs: more whimper than an evil bang|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/relationships/glitter-bombs-more-whimper-than-an-evil-bang/article22785816/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=3 November 2016}}</ref>
==In fiction== In the Season 3 premiere of ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', William McKinley High School teacher and Glee Club director [[Will Schuester]] glitter bombs cheerleading coach and candidate for the [[United States House of Representatives]] [[Sue Sylvester]] as a protest against her support for cutting federal funding for the arts in public schools. The tactic backfires, as Sue sees a boost in her poll numbers after the event is posted to [[YouTube]].
